title: Cat. 98  La Belle Dame Paresseuse, 1894

The sitter, shown resting indolently at one end of a sofa in this lithograph, was Beatrix Whistler. She appears to be almost asleep, a newspaper or magazine abandoned on her lap. Beatrix’s lassitude, recorded in several lithographs drawn in August and September 1894, may signal the onset of her fatal illness, diagnosed as cancer at the end of the year. Nevertheless, the theme of the recumbent female, posed casually either on a chair, a sofa, or in bed, was a recurrent one in Whistler’s work, from early drawings of Helen Ionides (M 336–38), drawings and etchings of Joanna Hiffernan (M 309, 310; K 92), and images of Maud Franklin in a variety of media (M 866, 867, 901–03; YMSM 254), to the late, intimate lithographs of Beatrix and members of her family (cat. 107, cat. 108, cat. 109, cat. 159, cat. 160, and cat. 175).

Before starting to draw this image, Whistler tried out his crayons—both pointed and blunt—on the right and left sides of the sheet of transfer paper. These small marks were allowed to remain on the stone after the image was transferred and apparently troubled neither the artist nor his printers. Close examination of impressions of the lithograph reveals evidence of an irregular texture in the surface of the transfer drawing. This can probably be attributed to uneven brush marks left on the papier végétal when its surface was coated with gum at Lemercier’s shop, where Whistler had recently been reintroduced to the transparent transfer paper.

As he waited impatiently for the Ways to send him the first proofs of Rue Furstenburg (cat. 97), Whistler sent off “another drawing” on the same transfer paper with a letter dated 17 August 1894 (letter 106). This drawing must have been La Belle Dame paresseuse. The artist subsequently referred to the two images together in letters to his dealers and printers, expressing his enthusiasm for the effects he had achieved with the French paper. In a letter he sent to the Ways on September 14, for example, he explained: “The newest and most beautiful quality I have reached is in ‘La Belle Dame Paresseuse.’ . . . Take a fine proof of this and put it beside any one of the old lithographs out of your portfolio—and then see how this ‘belle dame’ looks fair and silvery, and beautiful in the quality of blacks! Indeed far and away more like the charcoal drawing itself the painter—than anything that had ever been printed!—It is really also quite velvety—like . . . the burr in a dry-point!—Now even the little Rue de Furstenberg has also this same ‘fusain’ look—and no other paper has ever given it!” (letter 118).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Although the image is not mentioned by its title in the letter of August 17, its identity becomes clear in later letters. By August 22, proofs of three new lithographs (cat. 98, cat. 99, and cat. 100) had been printed by the Ways in London and sent to Whistler in Paris. On that date the artist wrote to tell the printers how pleased he was with the latest impressions, describing this drawing as “the other seated lady” to differentiate it from La Jolie New Yorkaise (cat. 99); letter 109.
